body:
That's the expected behavior.

`@Disabled` is not annotated with `@Inherited` and therefore only applies to the current class.

The Javadoc for `@Disabled` actually states that:

> `@Disabled` is used to signal that the annotated test class or test method is currently disabled and should not be executed.

I suppose we could add a sentence to point out that it is not `@Inherited`, but then we'd probably want to add similar notes to **every** conditional execution annotation -- such as `@EnabledOnJre`, `@DisabledOnOs`, etc.

I've changed the title of this issue to reflect that.

rename.from: @Disabled not working on abstract parent class
rename.to: Explicitly document that `@Disabled` is not inherited

body: @sbrannen Thanks for your answer, is there any way/workaround if I do want it works inherite-able ?

> is there any way/workaround if I do want it works inherite-able ?

No, there is no workaround to make `@Disabled` inherited. The JUnit 5 annotation search algorithms simply do not support that.

However, you should be able to implement a programmatic solution by registering a custom `ExecutionCondition` that always returns `disabled()`.

I'll see if I can spike a solution for you.

> `@Disabled` didn't mentioned it cannot be used on parent class, so I opened this issue.

After further investigation, I noticed that this is actually already documented in the [User Guide](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#writing-tests-annotations).

> Used to [disable](https://junit.org/junit5/docs/current/user-guide/#writing-tests-disabling) a test class or test method; analogous to JUnit 4â€™s `@Ignore`. Such annotations are not _inherited_.

In any case, I am adding a note to the Javadoc of each _conditional_ annotation and a note in the `Conditional Test Execution` section of the User Guide as well.

rename.from: Explicitly document that `@Disabled` is not inherited
rename.to: Document that `@Disabled` and conditional annotations are not inherited

body: @sbrannen Maybe we should let others known there is a workaround ... instead of the term `must be redeclared on the subclass.` ðŸ˜‚

> @sbrannen Maybe we should let others known there is a workaround ... instead of the term `must be redeclared on the subclass.` ðŸ˜‚

I suppose we could mention a workaround for `@Disabled`, but that would not apply to any of the other conditional annotations since their `ExecutionCondition` implementations are sometimes rather complex and are not `public`, meaning the logic would have to be re-implemented in each "workaround".

The only reason it _works_ for `@Disabled` is that there is zero logic in the "workaround".
Reopening for team discussion about inclusion of the workaround for `@Disabled`.
